text: I do have the same struggle to create a property where i can store the date with time. How did you set it as readOnlyValue and readOnlyDefinition?

I'm kinda in the same boat <@U01846Q3V6U> -- As I understand it you have a choice to create an app OR you can just use the same APIs with a single HubSpot account. Documentation is effectively the same for both, (I think)

I am a little perplexed however about what the status is with <https://github.com/HubSpot/HubSpot-api-python> .... there's no documentation on how to use the python SDK, all the examples in the docs don't use that software package, and it's only a couple months old.... it references the old api docs, not the new docs, what's going on there?

I think I got it figured out. It was much less complex than I was making it. I just had to create a form in conversations, then it provided me some embed code that I was able to use. So I didn't need the API at all.
Hello! is there an api for loading/creating snippets over API (snippets as in <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/conversations/use-snippets>)?
I am working on a Ticket project myself this week. I likely is that simple or almost that simple. Did you look at <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/tickets> yet?
Yeah... that's the Service Form route... less work to get out there but less customizable.
you have to do it via the create a contact property API

Building a new integration api v3 is the way to go right? The python SDK seems hot off the press and the documentation seems like a lot of endpoints aren't fully flushed out. Is there some "state of the api" post that explains where things are at and how they are moving
And the stream of updates that come along with it
I think the line `var goToHubSpot = document.querySelector("goToHubSpot");` is bad

You probably need a valid div, name, id, class, or other lookup flag set on the desired form snippet / portion of the HTML, in order for that line to pick up the desired object from the DOM, or it's just going to be NULL all the time which will get you the "not defined" uncaught exception.

This is coming from a non-JS / non-JS-GUI dev. so take it only under advisement, however I do have tons of experience with XML / HTML DOMs in backend document processing type of use cases, and I make basic bad non-JS web GUIs for internal tools and POCs.
I would break this code apart, and start way more simple, and just debug finding the object in the DOM first before trying to submit to HubSpot, using Browser Dev Tools debug breakpoints and such.
